summary.p: The [brother...], to whom Bullinger had entrusted Erb's elaborations of the writing "Resurrectio," has, after being ill for a while, finally returned to Bullinger and has returned to him the [planned dispatch to Erb]. Christoph [Froschauer] will print the treatise "De Iesu Christo... regnante in ecclesia sanctorum" before [September 29] and will preface the volume with the "Resurrectio." Erb should not take [the inconveniences caused] by Bullinger amiss. - Bullinger expects a response from Erb regarding [his appointment to] Augsburg, about which he did not write in the last letter [not received]. - The [people of Zurich] are well; however, the former schoolteacher Georg Binder passed away the day before. - Bullinger requests a reply; Erb could send it to [Johannes] Gast or [Oswald] Myconius in Basel. - Best wishes for the [Reichenweier city] scribe [Oswald FÃ¼rstenlob] and the [Zurich] Gerold Meyer [the Younger].

div.p: Greetings. I have been relieved of great concern, most learned Erb and dearest brother to me. The person to whom I had entrusted your chapters on the Resurrection, along with the dedicatory letter, has finally reached me, or rather returned, and has returned the letters entrusted to him along with the chapters, so that now everything is safe with me. He was bedridden for a while, and because he feared that sending them later might cause inconvenience, he returned and humbly gave them back. Therefore, since Christoph [Froschauer] will soon print our dissertation on the priest and king Christ reigning in the church, he will add the booklet on the Resurrection. It will be printed before the feast of St. Michael. I therefore pray that you continue to devote yourself to me and do not take anything amiss.

Regarding the matter (which you know) in Augsburg, about which I gave you some information in previous letters, I anxiously await a response. For the best people are also urging me. Therefore, see to it that you do not remain silent any longer.
We are all well here, except that Mr. Georg Binder, a learned and pious man, formerly a schoolmaster, has passed away, indeed the day before I wrote this.
Please respond to us. If you send it to Basel to Gast or Myconius, they will ensure it is delivered to me.
May your scribe, a sincere and good man, be safe, along with our Gerold. Farewell.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Matthias Erb, preaching Christ in Reichenweier, dearest brother. To the preacher in Reichenweier.
